# Day 697

Politics, with its inherent divisiveness and toxic nature, often fails as a meaningful measure of our lives. It's more likely to create rifts than to bridge them, presenting a framework that's hardly conducive to guiding our personal or shared experiences. The real value lies in the moments we share with friends and the authentic connections we aim to forge.

However, these are at risk of being overshadowed by the compulsion to convert others to our own ideological views. This pursuit, instead of drawing us closer, tends to erode trust and authenticity in our relationships. This principle is not exclusive to political debates but is also applicable to discussions about Bitcoin.

Despite its significant advantages, trying to convince others of its worth often proves to be futile. Prioritizing our shared values and experiences is infinitely more rewarding. By focusing on what unites us rather than what divides us, we strengthen our relationships and enhance our collective well-being. This approach fosters a more united and harmonious way of living, emphasizing the importance of commonality over conflict.

I'm grateful to have gotten the chance to hang with friends tonight and go on a triple date. Life is better when spent with people you love. Tonight my friends and I talked about passing on our legacy. Spreading our knowledge and wisdom to the next generation. Grateful I get the opportunity to do so.
